text: Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) is a pervasive and debilitating mental health condition that affects millions of individuals worldwide. Despite advances in treatment, many individuals continue to struggle with persistent symptoms, highlighting the need for innovative and effective interventions. This action research study aimed to co create and evaluate treatment strategies for PTSD in collaboration with individuals with lived experience, clinicians, and researchers. Employing a participatory action research design, we worked with stakeholder groups to develop and refine a tailored treatment program. Through a series of iterative feedback loops, we identified key components of effective treatment, including trauma focused cognitive behavioral therapy, emotional regulation skills, and social support networks. Preliminary findings suggest that this collaborative approach resulted in significant reductions in PTSD symptoms and improved overall well being. This study demonstrates the value of co creation in developing effective treatment strategies that address the complex needs of individuals with PTSD, ultimately promoting comprehensive and sustainable recovery. text: Here is an abstract for an Environmental Science paper on Web of Science "A 10 year longitudinal study examines the relationship between environmental pollutants and reproductive health outcomes in a cohort of 1,500 women. Exposure to particulate matter, arsenic, and pesticides is associated with increased risk of infertility, miscarriage, and birth defects. Temporal trends reveal that women living in areas with higher levels of pollution experience faster declines in reproductive function over time. These findings have significant implications for informing policies to mitigate the environmental burden on reproductive health and promoting healthy pregnancies and birth outcomes."
style: Longitudinal: Observes the same subjects over time to document changes and trends.
